Award.AwardTitle: Highly efficient numerical solution of the Boltzmann equation for practical applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Varghese, Philip L.
Proposal Number: 1438530

The goal of the proposed research is to develop an improved method to compute flows under conditions where the conventional continuum equations are invalid. If successful, the work would result in solution strategies for a broad range of applications where continuum equations fail. The work proposed will advance the state-of-the-art for hybrid flow simulations that are important in design and simulation of wafer fabrication machines, plasma processing equipment, and micro-sensors.

The continuum approach to fluid mechanics reaches its limitations in rarefied flows and in micro- and nanoflows. A commonly used approach for computing non-continuum flows is the direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) method, which can be thought of as providing a statistical representation of solutions of the Boltzmann equation by modeling the behavior of a large number of the molecules in the flow. This proposal is about a novel scheme to solve the Boltzmann equation numerically that has the potential to alleviate many of the limitations of DSMC, including feasibility for large scales. The proposed work is based on a new idea on how to compute the collisional integral, which appears in the Boltzmann equation and has been the reason for inefficient solutions and approximations to-date, using a projection into a discrete yet conservative velocity space. This approach can be viewed as a variation of DSMC that uses variable-mass fixed-velocity quasi-particles, rather than fixed-mass variable-velocity particles. Preliminary results show good agreement with theoretical predictions. The software developed during this project will be given to other academic and government laboratory users on request. The research center within the Institute for Computational Engineering and Sciences at UT Austin will be utilized for dissemination - it has established high standards for software documentation and code verification and validation.

This award by the Fluid Dynamics Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by CIF 21 Software Reuse Venture Fund Program of the CISE/ACI Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this work we have developed an improved method to compute gas flows under conditions where the continuum Navier-Stokes equations are invalid. Presently, these non-continuum flows are usually computed by the direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) method, which can be thought of as providing a statistical representation of solutions of the Boltzmann equation by modeling the behavior of a large number (but still a very small fraction) of the molecules in the flow. Our novel scheme to solve the Boltzmann equation numerically alleviates many of the limitations of DSMC. It can also be viewed as a complementary technique that uses variable-mass fixed-velocity quasi-particles, rather than the fixed-mass variable-velocity particles. The method uses variance reduction that minimizes statistical noise and significantly accelerates calculations. The computational scheme also has a number of controllable parameters that can be used to accelerate computations. For example, we have shown that steady state flows can be calculated rapidly by progressively reducing error tolerance on the collision integral calculations. We have also shown that heat flux and viscous stress can be calculated very accurately even when temperature and velocity gradients are small.

Discrete velocity simulations sometimes show spatial ripples in the computed property fields if the physical space grid is refined beyond a certain point. This phenomenon had been observed before but had not been studied extensively. We studied this behavior and isolated its origin to an interaction between physical and velocity space discretizations in the absence of collisional “mixing” of the discrete velocity distribution function. We showed that in the moderately rarefied conditions appropriate to most practical applications this effect can be ameliorated by using appropriate artificial viscosity for the convective term, e.g. with a Lax-Friedrichs scheme.

The quasi-particle viewpoint permits molecular internal energy distribution information to be incorporated at each point in velocity space and we have demonstrated that small population fractions in highly excited internal energy states can be computed accurately with very little statistical noise. This opens up the possibility of computing chemical and ionization reactions far more efficiently than with competing techniques. For the same computational accuracy we have demonstrated an order of magnitude reduction in computational expense relative to DSMC. We are currently studying the application of our technique to simulate gas breakdown.

Our quasi-particle simulation scheme is a powerful new technique for computing chemically reacting and ionizing non-equilibrium flows applicable for simulating the performance of industrially important devices such as plasma torches and high voltage switchgear.
